(0.025972782458089812) Here, people behave in a frightfully civilized manner in the face of adversity. (-0.01804656254625841) A well-heeled London solicitor, (Tom Wilkinson), discovers that not only is his wife having an affair with the local gentry but that she has also killed their housekeeper's husband in a hit-and-run accident. (-0.06473292398434645) He throws up, but otherwise his stiff-upper-lip hardly quavers. (-0.06942977142450636) Written and directed by Julian Fellowes, who won an Oscar for writing "Gosford Park", (this is his directorial debut), from a novel by Nigel Balchin (0.06896082636235636) , it's quite comical although I am not sure how much of the comedy is intended. (0.058166105991548304) It's like a throw-back to British films of the forties where characters all behaved like characters in books or plays rather than like people might in real life. (0.07167668255124328) However, it's not all bad. https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0184474
Deepa Mehta's "Fire" is groundbreaking, bold, and artistic. (0.04268356252784644) A masterful social commentary on the plight of the women from conservative, upper middle class Indian households, this is a film no one should miss. (0.041582716568768566) Shabana Azmi and Nandita Das give stellar performances by underplaying their characters as much as possible. (0.007626659288486411) A.R. Rahman's music is the work of the genius and almost plays the role of another character in the film. (0.020188011941391113) Mehta uses Rahman's score and together, they create such amazing sound montages that effectively portray the views of the world around Radha and Sita whenever they look to each other for support. (0.039671377931092135) This film is not about lesbianism as many have branded it. (0.029014191725994353) Lesbianism is just a part of the film. https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0184474
It is more a subtle story of the fact that in Indian household how most decisions are taken by the man, how no attention is paid to the desires of the lady, for example how even when the husband and wife sleep together it would be a test for the husband whether he can control his desires, not to give the woman pleasure. (-0.044661721847393976) And in such a type of scenario, women invariably have two choices, either to accept all this and take it into their own life, which is usually the case or not accept this and try to mould things to satisfy themselves, which makes a movie! (-0.04712111125578524) Fire is a brilliantly directed story of the second option, which women choose for themselves, no sacrifice, not to serve anybody else, rather a decision for their own good. (0.6405021123703708) Somehow the whole idea of justifying lesbianism didn't find an acceptance in the Indian audience but if one looks the whole movie from an angle of self-expression, then the whole debate doesn't even arise. (-0.22117822791165073)
positive: 71%

https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0184474
There are questions that sometimes hover over us and have no answer. (0.01722439812249505) Two women progressively find themselves ensnared in each other's arms (as corny as the expression sounds, that is exactly what happens) and fins that they cannot answer their own question as to what defines their relationship when their very own society has no name to what they are. (-0.009054904212409147) Deepa Mehta's somewhat mis-titled FIRE is the first of a loosely connected trilogy, here linked by the theme of the elements, and more symbolic than consuming. (0.08400857910984179) Fire as uncontrolled erotic passion does not make an appearance here, since the women -- the older and more feminine Radha (Shabana Azmi) and the younger, more masculine tempered Sita (Nandita Das) come to realize they share a lot more than common ideas and affection for each other and stand for what they believe is their passion for each other despite the opposition faced by their very traditional husbands and families. (-0.005305357572709591) As in WATER, FIRE is deeply spiritual, even if it technically falls into the mode of sentimental melodrama (where WATER, much like the weight of the word, carries a stronger meaning that ultimately transcends its definition). (0.09910400065766353) Even so, it's a very beautiful picture, and a strong voice from a strong director. (0.21484837849547836)

https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0184474
It's worth boning up on the Hindu pantheon before watching this film. (0.002013626867798663) Three main female deities -- wise Sita, nurturing Lakshmi and Kali the Transformer -- as well as three main male deities -- grave Rama, playful Krishna and Shiva the Ender -- are all alluded to. (0.01568837543788878) Knowing the folklore as surely every Indian member of an audience does lends a richness to the telling of the present-day story. (0.026756988305844262) In fact, one folktale is enacted first on stage, as part of a lesson in spirituality, and then in the movie's "real life." (0.013340499530117214) "Fire" speaks out against the misogyny and homophobia in the society to which its producers are native, and it does so with a beauty that weaves the message into multiple levels of the viewer's awareness, making it a deeply satisfying presentation. (0.03588611195657007) This is the finest film i've seen in the past ten years; very highly recommended! (0.05557091398548012)

https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0184474
This intelligent, moving and beautiful film is a study in the ways people react to tradition (reminds me of William Faulkner's novels). (0.16456813230748005) The characters all feel trapped by the weight of the roles they are expected to assume, and seek for a way to live within those roles rather than throw them off altogether. (0.0031069376260637197) But as the story develops the two wives, trapped in loveless marriages, draw together. (0.09104038867325621) Drawing on the strength of their friendship and love, they give each other the courage to abandon their roles. (0.09879532484982141) They have found that living within their traditions is no life at all, it is a sort of living death: without passion, without true connection to others, without fulfillment. (-0.08570709640881954) Although they know there will be a price to be paid for their rebellion and freedom, it is a price much less dear than the sacrifice called for by a comfortable, predictable existence. (-0.024286498318129096) The screenplay is wonderful, the acting marvelous. (0.12448710940774439) Near perfect! (-0.03071628641816719)

Anything Park Chan-wook creates is guaranteed to be unique, brilliant, and very twisted at a minimum. (0.07741631525086416) Well, anything that isn't I'm a Cyborg at least. (-0.008243875870757) Park's newest film titled Thirst is a vampire romance-erotic-thriller-dark comedy-drama ¬ñ yes, that is a lot of adjectives ¬ó inspired by the 19th century French novel by Emile Zola titled Therese Raquin. (0.06510998132029107) Park creates a uniquely Korean, and uniquely Park, vision of the vampire mythos and asks the audience to explore the dilemma of a Catholic priest discovering himself having a thirst for blood and the moral and spiritual crisis that would develop. (0.05892080425329095) Park delivers on the elements you would hope but definitely falls short of masterpiece quality like Oldboy or even that of Lady Vengeance. (-0.057628931278293105) Heavily bloated with a narrative that often loses itself much less the audience, Thirst desperately needed another trip through the cutting room. (-0.23120724220047922) It crawls when it should be running but luckily brings it back home before losing the audience completely. (0.03793786431883669) As negative as it may sound the positives definitely outweigh the negatives and another volume has without a doubt been added to the dark and twisted Zeitgeist of Park Chan-wook film. https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0762073
Although at times I was the only one in the cinema who was laughing, this is the main pleasure I took from the beautifully shot "Thirst" - laughter. (0.11234178090363152) Although sometimes it seemed that the movie had an identity crisis and didn't know whether it was a tragedy or a comedy, the blackest of black humour shone through at regular intervals. https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0762073
Of the Korean movies I've seen, only three had really stuck with me. (0.01882461571653721) The first is the excellent horror A Tale of Two Sisters. (0.08483155678187186) The second and third - and now fourth too - have all been Park Chan Wook's movies, namely Oldboy, Sympathy for Lady Vengeance), and now Thirst. Park kinda reminds me of Quentin Tarantino with his irreverence towards convention. (-0.07887548151449769) All his movies are shocking, but not in a gratuitous sense. (0.07211493254825758) It's more like he shows us what we don't expect to see - typically situations that go radically against society's morals, like incest or a libidinous, blood-sucking, yet devout priest. (-0.002367756472300218) He's also quite artistically-inclined with regards to cinematography, and his movies are among the more gorgeous that I've seen. (0.15470944373556786) Thirst is all that - being about said priest and the repressed, conscience-less woman he falls for - and more. (-0.00626345918922309) It's horror, drama, and even comedy, as Park disarms his audience with many inappropriate yet humorous situations. (0.18693354755504116) As such, this might be his best work for me yet, since his other two movies that I've seen were lacking the humor element that would've made them more palatable for repeat viewings. (-0.034674755870632304)
positive: 96%
label: pos

(-0.034824748880592414) This is the film you want to see if you want to remember the sticky thrills of the past... (0.060887861501763556) well, at least in the second half. (0) 'Thirst' starts out with a lengthy character exposition culminating in a slightly different love story. (0.043244347518647176) The vampire transformation of a priest is, over quite some time, sidelined by the romantic and sexual aspects of the story, which makes for some awkward viewing. (0) But the last 40 minutes or so are surprisingly gory. (0.05598395169967134) Well, maybe not so surprisingly if you know 'Oldboy' (-0.021337033851501895) and 'I'm a Cyborg (0) but that's OK', (0.042722016821491314) but I guess it's fair to say that 'Thirst' beats Park's earlier films in terms of in-your-face violence. (0.025838308366000592) All in all, be warned that this is neither art cinema nor a horror flick. (0) It may be too disgusting for many and too tame for some. (0.014652917821313007) Add a temptress leading him astray and a cast of eccentrics and you have a wonderful recipe. (0) Directed in part in a style similar to the "Sympathy" trilogy (-0.008291346805483038) it's as sumptuous as it is dark. (0.010527044402075999) Steering clear of clich√© it does offer some new tricks in the overdone vampire genre. (0) Its an existential movie trying to capture the moral conundrum of how exactly a person has to choose to live with their conditions rather than revel in the blood lust. (0) However, the film doesn't take itself too seriously and there is boundless humour throughout. (0.006346486558725905) Our leads play their roles to perfection, playing with our emotions and revelling in the dark humour. (0.01201685959247534) There are moments of reflection on the whole moral conundrums involved in the film but its never preachy. (0.009006176697140676) Some might find it overlong and it can lull at points (0) but it's worth giving it a chance to the end. (0.027976427336483513) If you like left field films then there are fewer better than this one of late. (-0.006333465523503491) Dark and engrossing, it will pull in a crowd. https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0762073
If you love Chan-wook Park, you know what to expect. (-0.009025554161542998) His films are brutal, poetic, tragic, and artistic, with splashes of very grim humor. (0) THIRST is clearly Park's style, and I loved every second of it, from the cinematography (every shot is gorgeous and creative) to the story, which blends Shakespearean tragedy, murderous love, Gothic horror, and layered character drama. (0.01700777441493648) The characters are complex and there is plenty of moral ambiguity to go around. (-0.006804673961315588) Even the most sociopathic character evokes sympathy. (0.011592088516942848) The direction is restrained and the performances are nuanced - like SYMPATHY FOR MR. (0) VENGEANCE, there are too many subtleties to take in on the first viewing. (-0.01110725280605954) Chan-wook Park is an intelligent, bold, consistently surprising filmmaker. (0.016483274302338088) It's unpredictable - scenes go from brutal and heart-wrenching to laugh-out-loud hilarious in an instant. (0) This is closer to LADY VENGEANCE then SYMPATHY FOR MR. (0.011615216903806028) VENGEANCE as far as being over-the-top and comical. (0) But, like LADY VENGEANCE, it's incredibly rich, thought-provoking, and rewarding. (0.016414968528673482) If you like beautifully told vampire stories (LET THE RIGHT ONE IN) or are a fan of Chan-wook Park, seeing THIRST should be obvious. Not being the least bit familiar with the characters from the comic book series, I expected this film to merely accomplish the basic: introduce me to the characters and their inherent characteristics, present a plot, and end with the destruction of the main adversary and perhaps hint at the possibility of a sequel. (-0.020616782324139285) And that's exactly what this movie happens to deliver. (-0.024867079341670633) However, unlike with most other comic book movies, I felt that this one did it with a bit of class. (0.040912188440508174) Risking a more limited audience with strong language and graphic fight scenes, "Blade" presents a very modern, believable and dismal world whose little nuances effectively managed to elicit a sense of dread--as minor as it may have been--from a viewer who rarely ever becomes involved in a story unless an emotional (i.e., sappy) aspect is concerned. (0.0742684531635364) Yes, the movie has innumerable plotholes, and preposterously unrealistic situations such as a standard female doctor being astute enough to contrive what no one else has been able to for several thousand years. (-0.10880769155166031) But when you have an enemy as cool as the one in this movie, and fight scenes with involving and exciting camera cuts and special effects such as this, what else matters? (0.11834434975663295) It may run a little long, but for what it sets out to do, "Blade" stands out in sharp relief among most other movies in this genre. (0.3376558978226487)

https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0149691
Wayne Wang's direction may be the ingredient which made this film much more impressive to me than "Slums of Beverly Hills", which covers remarkably similar ground. (0.019045258065309493) The interplay between Susan Sarandon and Natalie Portman is riveting. (0.02649812284338985) Real chemistry there. (-0.0016582670886027856) This film succeeded in bringing me inside the dysfunctional life of these two women without dragging me down into depressed frustration. (0.019954478464933794) Susan Sarandon's character hammers at all the nerves which a narcissistic parent is capable of touching in an insecure adolescent. (0.01744295708409046) She amazingly manages to do this without coming across as floridly insane or intentionally sadistic. (-0.005036044480829958) And, Natalie Portman deflects each attack on her character's ego with the resigned grace of an intelligent codependent child, untainted by the smug cynicism of the Natasha Lyonne character in "Slums of Beverly Hills". (-0.002632804038153553) Portman's character is an adolescent with dignity under stress, an unusual creature in modern films. (0.01097386301135877) The film reaches a very satisfying resolution without trying too hard. https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0069994
As a late-going patron of the drive-in thearers (1970's-1980s), there are many movies that I have seen & forgotten. (0.013259167342217944) This is one I could never forget. (0.023252554560786155) Despite its low-budget, exploitation-style of movie-making, the STORY was very well done. (0.04693725377347292) The isolated therapy-asylum, where patients act out their fantasies in order to help cure their phsycosis, the accidental murder of the head doctor just as the new nurse arrives on the scene, the (supposed) assistant doctor taking over, the various crazy paitents, the revelation that the assistant doctor is actually a patient herself, and, finally, the rescue of the young nurse by the simple-minded Sam, who killed everyone else in the house so she could escape unharmed, made for a great STORY, which held the film together. (0.03749614211996577) I emphasised the word STORY because that's what makes a good or great film. (0.04000686843986992) No matter how much blood, gore, nudity, sexual matter, or outrageous behaviour you put in a film, if the STORY is not good, then the film is not good. (-0.057110481678374736) The film credits show clips of all the actors, including the old hag with the final line telling you to get out & never come back, which is a great ending to this film. (0.06409298699618134) If it is out on video/DVD, see it & enjoy it. (0.06158482153281876)
positive: 99%
label: pos

(0.28678118885947357) Though the movie seems to go nowhere throughout the first hour+ of (0.15362283582362712) it's runtime (-0.08872253651393126) , I enjoyed this particular batch of quirky crazies and their various personalities and deficiencies - such as the former army sergeant, a chick obsessed with caring for a plastic doll, a lovable man-child, and a loony nymph. (0.049682591030806335) After their head-doctor is murdered by a patient, a small sanitarium hires a new nurse onto their under-staffed facility, who becomes immersed in the resident's different "ticks" and outbursts. https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0069994
Although it isn't mentioned very often, "Don't Look in the Basement" is a very interesting film and is definitely worth a watch. (0.01349329203035047) The story follows a young nurse, Charlotte Beale, who is hired at Stephen's Sanitarium to replace Dr. Stephens, after he is murdered by a patient. (0.007940250986466935) Many patients begin to torment Miss Beale, and her boss, Dr. Geraldine Masters, acts as if she's hiding something... (-0.008040185094890498) This movie has many appealing characters that you actually end up caring about, and have sympathy for during the climax, which doesn't happen very often in horror films. (0.004659226877569708) The musical score is great and is reminiscent of "Dark Shadows," the performance from Rosie Holotik, Rhea McAdams, and Bill McGhee are all great, the story is very intriguing with a great twist ending. (0.011901917088185157) This movie has a campy atmosphere around it that no other film I have ever seen has been able to capture. (0.012185300692083458) Many horror fans have never seen or even heard of this film which is really unfortunate because it could have been a horror classic. (0.003545602174095482) "Don't Look in the Basement" is definitely worth watching for all fans of 1970s drive-in films. (0.010798350403356213)

https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0069994
'Don't Look In the Basement' is so easy to knock but the truth is simply that Brownrigg is one of Horrors real underground stars and IMHO is vastly overdue some proper recognition. ' (0) Don't' is his undisputed masterpiece. (0.2974779569076491) This scummy psychodrama snags the viewer straightaway into such an odd, disjointed, claustrophobic world of sweating insanity (-0.17636754197368873) you have no real idea what the hell is going on. (-0.038266631270447514) It succeeds in making you feel strangely dirty, just plain grubby, for Brownrigg's world is this mad, unwashed, scummy prison cell of rants, obsessions and all shades of mental illness. (0) And he uses his low budget palette to wrap his grot blanket around you like a bad memory. (0.029924620973077274) There is just something so beautifully odd about the whole damn thing. (0.09125546867080163) In a word, classic.... (0.11883289090492574) Also, if you watch 'Don't' first then you will have some idea of the insane psychodrama style that marks Brownrigg's other films. (0.06831918159984006) In summary they really don't come any more esoteric than this - well, actually they do, track down Brownrigg's 'Keep My Grave Open'. (-0.09643720353575484) Mad genius. (0.1242530534922713) Accept no substitute. (-0.03692357135245781)

https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0069994
Yet another in the long line of "Don't" films of the late 70's and early 80's yet this one is much more than that. (0.03913267756679383) This film is a highly underestimated low budget schlocker with a twist. (-0.14575760416960243) It has the grainy quality and bizarre soundtrack that is typical of horror films of the time period but it's the highly underestimated performances of the surprisingly talented actors/actresses that make this movie good. (0.4137956324209996) A young nurse arrives at Dr. Stephens' progressive mental hospital right after he has been murdered by one of his patients and all is not what it appears to be. (0.017252994370801415) It seems Dr. Masters, a rather ambitious female doctor, has taken over his duties and begun to implement her own ideas. (-0.07550632136178043) Each of the patients take on their own unique personalities and have their own personality traits and flaws which make for highly entertaining interactions. (0.17007982753117792) There is the nymphomaniac, the crazy old crone, the woman with an unhealthy obsession with infants, and a man who has reverted back to his childhood among others. (0.012444751258710036) There is also a strange little twist to this bizarre story that later finds the young nurse trapped inside the asylum with the patients running around loose and bodies piling up. (0.008573416501978433) If you are a fan of cheap 70's sleaze than this is the film for you! (-0.17174201077252269)

The impossibly sexy Rosie Holotik plays Charlotte Beale, a new nurse at one of those movie-type asylums where the doctor in charge has his own, unorthodox ways of treating the inmates. (-0.062103019534420496) Reluctantly bringing her on board is the officious Dr. Masters (Anne MacAdams, a.k.a. Annabelle Weenick). (0) The inmates don't take too kindly to Charlotte, either. (-0.046996726940764295) Part mystery, part horror, (0.04685192368581758) this initial effort from B-movie director S.F. Brownrigg has an oppressive feel to it. (0) These colorful psychos, including a nymphomaniac with no self-esteem, a gentle giant who's already had a lobotomy, and a supposed "judge" who speaks in legalese jargon, dominate the screen with their unnerving presence. (-0.09303236355588558) It's a picture that works fairly well, establishing the gritty, grim atmosphere right from the get go. (0.22739387906910477) Some brief bursts of graphic violence also help to give it that good old fashioned exploitative quality. (0) It builds in intensity as the imperiled heroine struggles to maintain her own sanity, offering one surreal encounter after another. (-0.010434214979973435) Particularly effective is the poetry-quoting, dotty old Mrs. Callingham. (0.031469221586925104) For cheap 1970's era cheese, it's pretty effective, with a particularly nasty climax. (0.01908166501722063) I had a pretty good time watching it. (-0.016224647961497772) While it is true that Grint is stone-faced like a redheaded Benjamin Braddock for the first half of the movie, it does not deter from the quirky family film--there are things going on that are out of his character's experience that would create a shell-shocked reaction. (-0.028180947893988118) The chemistry between Walters and Grint carries the film, though Laura Linney's hard work to make her written stereotype human is also notable. (0.12938903773993843) These performances combined with a fun poppy soundtrack with artists like Sufjan Stevens, John Renbourn and Salsa Celtica make this kids popcorn flick worth a Saturday afternoon. https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0037595
Barbara Stanwyck is a sheer delight in this wartime comedy, about a sailor invited to spend Christmas with a popular magazine writer's family, at her farm in Connecticut. (0.044763393558994696) The problem is she has no husband, baby, or farm, as she writes about in her column, and she can't even cook; her wonderful recipes being provided for her by her good friend " Uncle" Felix, owner of a Hungarian restaurant in New York City. (-0.012541235289369106) Things get even more complicated when her strict publisher boss invites himself along for Christmas. (-0.005916304810520109) A scheme is hastily planned, with her stuffy fianc√© providing an actual Connecticut farm, neighbors providing a borrowed baby, and a quick wedding planned when the publisher isn't looking. (-0.0116363905773997) But when the handsome young sailor arrives on Christmas Eve, romantic complications ensue, as the supposedly married author falls like a ton of bricks for the nice guy Navy man and vice versa. (0.011167160364412187) This is a charming, warm film that deftly balances humor with sentiment and is a wonderful showcase for Barbara Stanwyck to display her considerable comedic talent, aided by such marvelous character actors as Sydney Greenstreet, Una O'Connor, S.Z.Sakall, and many others. (0.07817095751957222) A Christmas night dance at the town hall is a toe tapping delight to see, and the unexpectedly sweet and feminine side of Stanwyck is a wonderful surprise, for viewers who have seen her mainly as tough, bitchy women in femme fatale roles. (0.05773431283010746) Truly a wonderful film that has stood the test of time. (0.06793561815660505)

(0) His intention is to get some money and rifles as ransom for them, to fight against the corrupt Sultan of Moroco (Marc Zuber). (0.007330600493458776) However, Raisuli is betrayed and Eden helps him to be released from the prison with the American soldiers. (0.009137239668245511) El Raisuli (Sean Connery) head of an Arab tribe kidnaps an American woman(Candice Bergen) and her two children to obtain some concessions for his country out of American president Theodore Roosevelt (Brian Keith). (0.00005374030937491264) Out of this simple plot John Milius gets a very complete and enjoyable movie in the genre. (0.0011667381823628291) The outdoor dessert locations, an impressive color photography, very well handled action sequences and perfect settings turn the picture in a sort of epic one with an undeniable sense of greatness. (0.012261620251405396) The musical score is also remarkable an fits accordingly. (0.006223968978484339) Sean Connery is very good as the Arab leader and proofs he can handle almost any kind of role. (0.0015523684360905217) So is Candice Bergen as the woman who shows strength under dangerous circumstances but deep inside is scared and has her weaknesses; she gets to admire Connery and even understand his complete different focus on life arising from their also completely different cultures. (0.005828806251682463) Brian Keith plays one of his best roles ever as American president Teddy Roosevelt. (0.0037110294411896692) Most entertaining and very good cinematographic sample in the genre. (0.014614647427947531) Give it chance, you won't regret it. (0.0020900783694095533)

(0) Also, the music is really cool. (0) But what is very unique in this musical (as opposed to Evita, or Wizard of Oz, for example) is that the lyrics don't tell the story. (0.010692465414808413) The mood does (along with the visuals and between-songs-dialog): "Donna" is an upbeat song which emphasizes the happy mood, whereas "Flesh Failures" has a driving, intense beat, in a minor key. (-0.0038383411176543683) This small group happens upon a young man, Claude Bukowski (played by John Savage) who has been drafted into the US Army for service in Vietnam. (0.016054369831124286) Despite their best efforts to dissuade him, Claude does eventually report for basic training in the Army. (0.016718154491391492) Still distressed over his having left them, the hippie group steal a car and travel across the USA to visit Claude "...for a couple of hours," in the words of George Berger (to an M.P. stationed at the entry gate of the Army base Claude is temporarily stationed at in Nevada). Brit director Chrstopher Nolan now has a career in America, and a reputation for making movies both popular and critically acclaimed; but this small film was where he started. (0.01896252834457211) And it certainly showcased his talent, with its striking black-and-white cinematography and achronological storytelling that prefigures his later 'Momento', albeit in a less extreme way. (0.11796834832873157) Thematically and mechanistically, the plot reminded me of David Mamet's 'House of Games', but the film still feels fresh and sharp, right up to the final twist of the ending whose flavour was expected, but whose pointedness is unexpectedly delicious. (0.1564982306493509) The acting, on the other hand, is not quite in the same class - the film has a stylised quality, and possibly to a greater extent than the director intended. (-0.003425723324155967) But it's still a fine debut, simultaneously claustrophobic and beguiling. (0.14909123678421338)

https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0154506
The debut that plucked from obscurity one of the brighter stars of contemporary noir is an assured, if limited, stab at the con game and obsession. (0.09634673007379964) Filmed for zero money, Nolan couldn't have chosen a better subject than the drab and seamy underside of London to ply his trade, given the lack of funds. (-0.10201309437800632) This short (67 min) is at its best in playing with the audience's and protagonist's expectations about who is scamming whom, though the initial set-up does ring some alarm bells in the credibility dept. (0.034522142350103056) The muddy cinematography (he often used natural lighting due to budget) can be mostly chalked up to noir stylization, though the limitations do show at times. (-0.06929913389862394) One can easily see Nolan's style developing in this fledgling effort; many of the same themes of blurred identity and expectation smashing recur in MEMENTO and INSOMNIA. (0.01899571648115369) Not a masterpiece but good and certainly worth a look for modern noir and Nolan fans. (0.3234790703329042)

(0.2039409173413044) Just watching his frenzied writhing and screaming and destructive rage near the end of the film is enough to make anyone think twice about trying heroin; maybe they should show this to kids in health class instead of the mindless drivel we are compelled to endure year after year. (-0.011535169122816288) It's the story of a man who is simply trying to make a new, clean life for himself after being in prison, trying to rid himself of his drug habit and his job of dealing cards in illegal gambling operations, who is pulled down, pulled back into the muck by the evils of human nature. (0.10556019345618212) He is being taken advantage of by his employers, the drug dealers, and even his enigmatic, crafty-yet-stupid wife. (0.024273455469346217) Even if you didn't like the film itself, it's worth seeing just for the soundtrack. (0.027582080354847455) It's all heavy, swinging jazz with large drum and brass sections. (0.05940202798592066) This, with its groovy, yet slightly sinister sound, helps set the mood, along with the grinning, snaky drug and card dealers, who always seem to hover like vultures around Frankie Machine. https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0048347
Lots of scenes and dialogue are flat-out goofy, but when you add it all up, i.e. Machine's daily cycle from depressing walkup to depressing bar to depressing burlesque hall to depressing smoke-filled poker games and back home again, you get a weird sense that somebody, somewhere is trying to give a faithful depiction of the junkie's life circa-1955. (-0.02453748702411598) Whether it's Sinatra, who obviously would have bumped up against this type of character growing up in Hoboken and working in numerous bands, or Preminger, who uses the soundtrack and the Frankie-Zosch subtext to slip the addict's interior worldview past the Hays Code cage, you get a good companion piece to (0.3919238486336292) On the Waterfront, which was filmed almost exactly the same time. (0.03946304478138052) Sort of a faux-realist work that leaves you realistically wondering how deep the drug culture is embedded in American life. (0.15061999760086428)

https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0048347
Otto Preminger's "The Man with the Golden Arm" is a reference to heroin addiction - something that must have been rather risky to film back in 1955, fifty years ago (the censors today STILL have a problem with drug content in films!). (0.0036625126077411718) The lead role was originally offered to Marlon Brando, then snatched by Frank Sinatra before Brando could respond. (0.00589264432433968) Sinatra convincingly portrays a pro card dealer and ex-heroin addict who returns home to the city only to find himself battling the demons of temptation. (0.026637312150499713) Preminger is one of my favorite directors (his "Anatomy of a Murder" starring James Stewart is a brilliant and revolutionary courtroom drama). (0.0774900684974912) Preminger pretty much helped change the face of cinema back in the '50s - "Anatomy of a Murder" was extremely controversial when it came out due to both its plot and content (references to rape, women's "panties," seduction, etc.) (0.010313472310015746) and "The Man with the Golden Arm" deals with a topic that is equally volatile. (0.05503706685714083) However, Preminger pulls it off without becoming exploitative. (-0.03578949826417504) This is like a forerunner to "The Panic in Needle Park" (1971) and bears more than a few similarities in terms of general motifs to the classic Billy Wilder movie "Lost Weekend," starring Ray Milland. (0.01721719332411281) These three films in particular are probably the best movies about alcoholism predating the 1980s and still remain relevant today. (0.20387955264232105)

(0.03334629894593106) The dialogue is minimal, so his face must register the nuances of his anguished character - a composer (a writer in the novelette - the only major alteration) who travels to Venice in 1910. (-0.00344277246446673) Visconti revels in the portrayal of beauty, it's passing, and the whiff of decay beneath. (0.05975055537128652) Trained as an opera director, Visconti blends Mahler's music and imagery seamlessly in his finest film since "The Leopard" (another stunning film, which greatly influenced Coppola's Sicily in the "Godfather"). (0.07860708739500565)

(0.034073854356984117) Death in Venice is one of very few films with the patience and bravery to tackle this fact head-on. (0.10514181719165831) It confronts the human eye with beauty and inspiration in their two most inevitable human forms-self denial and decay. (0.0577147332167627) Undoubtedly this is the greatest film to have no discernable influence on mainstream cinema. (0.00730115563009655) Its austerely refined look, echoey sound, mixture of unsubtitled languages, and highly challenging themes being impossible to copy: as much an accident of its peculiar production as of the vision of its director. (0.04033579731100845) Things start to go awry when Tatoya, the maid, murders Yegor and William and a mad scientist implants a piece of Yegor's brain in William's head. (-0.02039747326538527) The Man (0.027074291125778617) With The Screaming Brain is an incredibly funny film. (0.29345999536679673) It has the most hilarious tracking shot I have ever seen (when Bruce Campbell's character, fresh from the lab and complete with giant forehead scar and blue hospital pajamas, runs into a square and scares a crowd of people) and a falling-down-the-steps murder scene that had the entire test screening audience screaming laughing. https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120907
Fair and nifty little science fiction/horror fantasy thriller about a well-known video game designer, Allegra Geller (Jennifer Jason Leigh) whose latest game - "eXistenZ" not only draws the attention of people who volunteer to try the game, but one who nearly kills her (and her game, too). (0.04599939234076884) Since she forced to stay out of sight, Allegra is stuck with Ted Pikul (Jude Law), a marketing trainee ("P.R. nerd") to be her bodyguard even though he only has a gun that's made out of flesh and bone and the bullets are teeth. (-0.034736801020772284) Director David Cronenberg has, well, used some bits from his earlier films ("Videodrome", "Scanners", "The Fly", etc.) and placed it into certain parts of the story with some good timing. (0.13268453607496977) Law and Leigh are fine here and so are some of the supporting cast (Ian Holm, Willem Dafoe, Sarah Polley, Christopher Eccelston, and so on) that has an international twist to it. (-0.016613568674904745) Dafoe is anything but devilish as Gas, a deceiving garage mechanic. (0.007362571875884811) One of the movie's best scenes is witnessing Ted eat (fish and frogs) and construct a gun and admit to Allegra - " I can't help myself." (0.11405474210292083) "eXistenZ" manages to show that he (Cronenberg) is up to his old tricks and it still works like a charm. (0.1674413671743178)

https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120907
David Cronenberg movies are easily identifiable, or at least elements within the movie stand out as his trademarks. (0.018265135079853296) Fetishism, the blurring between the organic and inorganic, squishy throbbing things that shouldn't be squishy and throbbing. " (-0.027182202704311362) eXistenZ" is classic Cronenberg. (0.08806379329629417) Briefly, it's about a future generation of computer games, but instead of a video monitor, visuals are supplied by your mind. (-0.016389026631262144) The game plugs directly into a 'bio port' in the base of your spine and while the game is running, the player can't tell reality from game. (-0.025907608379571578) Jennifer Jason Leigh plays the game's developer, guiding a novitiate marketeer, Jude Law, through the game's paces. (0) While in the game they uncover strange goings-on and possible crimes. (-0.04344241057446196) But are they real, or is it the game? (-0.004292833430515188) Not even the game's author knows. (0) The movie is quite a treat, keeping the viewer engaged, but in the dark until the final minutes. (0.13783798284780815) Another thing I like about "eXistenZ" is that it doesn't use a heavy reliance on special effects, it's the story itself that propels the movie. (0.10095610771580273) Recommended for the Saturday night when science fiction is called for. (0.10324858350068823)

(0.0500928965874699) And it actually works effectively. (0.08954038229235099) I won't bother trying to give even the bare bones of a plot synopsis here because it'll only cause more confusion. (0.01907821523702659) All you need to know is that the film is about a virtual reality computer game that is so incredibly lifelike that it becomes difficult to tell the difference between reality and virtual reality. (0.014436149169136674) The film almost seems to abandon its technology fearing point at the end, but then it throws in the final twist in the very last line of dialogue. (0.018200171182612766) There's also some very gross sexual imagery based around the 'bio-ports' in the protagonists backs, as well as some very gross acting from Jude Law. (-0.4065234116300731) He manages to come off as naive and stupid and boring and any other annoying habit you can care to think of. (-0.0787721258913676) Jason Jennifer Leigh comes off much better, and everyone else can be called a supporting character, including Willem Dafoe in a functional, if unspectacular, role as a money-crazed mechanic. https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0202470
ROCK STAR is a well-told Hollywood-style rendition of the tale based on fact actually on how Ripper became Rob Halford's replacement for Judas Priest. (0.01791350170511096) Mark Wahlberg poured on his likable boy-ish charm and performed with believable admirably, something he has been known to do since the release of BOOGIE NIGHTS. (-0.002940516765167451) Stephen Herek, no stranger to musically-themed movies, takes the audience through the wonders of the breakneck lifestyle of an extinct species, the Hair-Metal Rock God. (-0.00044467814467808516) Wahlberg's "Izzy" acts as the film's host plays the everyman who gets to see his wish come true. (0.017793579281620894) His likable character quickly wins over the heart of the viewer, who wants to see him succeed and gets the chance to give him the Metal "goat horn" hand-sign several times over. (0.023674299427587645) The only real complaint with the story is that the supporting cast, namely the other members of the band, were not fleshed out, or even introduced, properly. (-0.013276835068425323) More interaction with these life-long Rock musicians would have amplified and solidified Izzy's new surroundings. (-0.003343964008057144) Naturally, ROCK STAR is filled with great music. (0.05996919585784364) Rabin's score, the Steel Dragon's original work and plenty of 80's-style Metal hits makes this soundtrack a must-have! (0.06352434458116353) Let's all hope that films like ROCK STAR not only give a credibility to a style of music that helped define a generation but also spark a very-needed revival. (0.03059631509380201)
positive: 99%

(0.05106560677406697) There are plenty of reasons to prematurely dismiss this movie for sure. (-0.011883930917663103) Among them: its length, its technical problems, its colossal mistreatment of animals on set -- the list goes on and on. (-0.01206997434978934) And yet, for all of this, it remains a film that captures something. (0.08847072590628813) It is a classic example of naturalistic storytelling on par with Strindberg -- its moments lasting as long as they might in reality, having not been dumbed down for good cinematic timing. (0.07323473076442345) It feels real in its moments of anger, love, and war (and hopelessness). (0.05426395069046789) This film should be seen by any person who appreciates film and storytelling. Mankind's Self awakening is the theme of "2001: A Space Odyssey", a process that unfolds along a space-time continuum. (0) We "see" our primordial past, and we "infer" a cosmic future. (0) The powers of intuition thus become the doors of perception, in our ongoing collective journey. (0) From this transcendental perspective, a conventional, egocentric plot seems superfluous. (-0.03458014760933645) Our frenzied conflicts and self-important dialogue are consumed in evolutionary change, and are irrelevant in a cosmos that is vast beyond comprehension. (0) It's a tough lesson for a vain and aggressive species. (0) Not surprising then that some of us huff and puff about the film's slowness and minimal story. (-0.043033844734697325) For perceptive viewers, the remuneration is an inspirational sense of wonder and awe. (0) In this film, which is mostly visual, geometric symbols guide our intuition. (0.09142330994154801) Circles and arcs represent nature. (0) Right angles represent conscious intelligence. (-0.024065258466585332) Some people think the sleek, black monolith is a Von Neumann probe. (0) Maybe. (-0.06551101534246968) Without doubt, the monolith is a visual metaphor for an extraterrestrial intelligence whose physical form is never shown. (0) Mystery is more profound than explanation. (0.07285049101328253) "2001 ... " is unique among films in content and scope. (0.04968856860486883) The cinematography is out-of-this-world, the special and visual effects are breathtaking, and the classical music is sublime. https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0171580
Renee Zellweger absolutely shines as Nurse Betty, easily one of the most charming, off-beat, and lighthearted comedies of the year. (0.0554419167115376) When soap opera obsessed waitress Betty Sizemore witnesses her insensitive husband's murder by two hitmen (Morgan Freeman and Chris Rock), she snaps and thinks the cast members on A Reason to Love are real. (-0.01772715817898508) She decides to travel to Los Angeles to find famed heart specialist Dr. David Ravell (a character on the show). (0.03468238082605677) As the two oddly paired Hitmen, the caustic Rock and the pontificating Freeman generate some very fun chemistry, and Greg Kinnear also has fun with his smarmy offscreen actor persona. (-0.007120273749970165) Renee Zellweger turns in an innocent, candy-coated, and sometimes terribly sweet performance as Nurse Betty. (-0.006120122111244366) She exudes goodness, warmth, and is irresistible. (0.03235077207621944) While the script sometimes feels like a sit-com, is filled with sometimes unbelievable characters and contrived situations, Zellweger is so likeable and so utterly disarming that it all comes together. (0.030284049263022746) With just a few splashes of black comedy to keep things interesting, a winning performance from Zellweger, a great supporting cast and a competent script, Nurse Betty is utterly delightful. (0.059066313365691264) 7 out of 10 (0.028033676463543402)

(0.010942117714156117) That being said, though, what hit me with particular force was what I take, possibly incorrectly, to be its Art Direction. (-0.019503568025163693) Many of the interior shots feature a rich concoction of color blends seemingly based on very understated Munsell Color Model progressions and complementary juxtapositions. (0.015208157367310878) This makes the movie probably unrealistic to contemporary eyes, but, to me, very beautiful as an aesthetic work in itself. (0.022128629755533896) I thought Victor Mature was well cast and Peter Ustinov a real gem! (0.1939771196987381) What Novak wants in return from Deane is whereabouts of Stargher's latest victim is and if she's alive. (0.024054036324294606) Once Deane gets into Stargher's mind, which has the appearence and atmosphere that resembles a colorful combination of David Lynch's "Dune" or "Blue Velvet" and (-0.006868736362405465) Wes Craven's "A Nightmare on Elm Street", the adventure begins. (0.03579154546580938) Deane sees a variety of odd people ranging from Carl as a youngster (an adorable Jake Thomas) to a Freddy Krueger-like man minus the razor claws. (-0.006536610057929001) I don't want to give away the ending, but the movie is great altogether besides the dynamite performances, Howard Shore's creepy musical score and directing (by Tarsem, who shows here that he can direct). (0.0644569717294031) The story surrounds the entry into society of Catherine Moreland. (-0.004378640488004594) Somewhat awkward and possessed of an unhealthy interest in Gothic stories (early pulp fiction?), Catherine descends on Bath in the company of Mrs Allen where she meets Henry Tilney. (-0.03486974524890833) She is invited to visit the Tilneys at Northanger Abbey, the seat of the formidable (and somewhat financially challenged) General Tilney, who has the unfortunate misconception that there is wealth afoot. (0.01812908018710352) Where mutual attraction mixes with family finance, dispute is inevitable. (0) This coupled with Catherines vivid imagination, leads her to fear for her safety. (0.02065595101648389) Her eventual departure is marred by accusations and counter accusations of deception and connivance. (0) But the attraction between Catherine and Henry stands these trials. (0.023221973649920093) He returns to provide a happy ending. (-0.011994672544463677) This final scene is especially compelling, given the incidental music of Ilona Sekacz. https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0082592
Just Before Dawn really surprised me when I saw it by being far less of a gruesome horror adventure than I expected. (0.018335310784655633) Instead the director Jeff Lieberman conjures up a wonderfully evocative and disquieting atmosphere for great stretches of the movie, building the suspense constantly until I was really unsure about what was going to happen but wound up tight as a spring waiting for it. (0.06666554761971845) The lack of action in many parts gave it a very Deliverance mixed with The Texas Chainsaw Massacre kinda ambiance, and when the action really kicks in, its truly shocking and dramatic, without ever even really needing to be gory. (0.029239548253867532) The characters are about par for this kind of movie, though more sympathetic than some, and the bad guy memorably freaky. (-0.0150518883450698) The photography and suspense are the real winners in this movie and they keep it from ever being dull (as has been suggested). (0.08058000290615484) I firmly recommend this one to serious horror fans. (0.07155367818001472) Don't expect gore, do expect a creepy backwoods tale with several awesome moments and a great dreamlike ambiance. (0.022288813261215144)

(0) Just Before Dawn is a step ahead of the typical backwoods slasher flick. (0.08570894800156593) The cinematography is gorgeous. (0.1229765864323857) The acting is top notch. (0.04188549516378442) The heroine of the film is not your typical 'final girl'. (0) Constance is a 'woods' girl, but when it comes down to the primal instinct of survival, she's a step behind. (0) Not until it comes to saving the life of her and her boyfriend, does the primal notion of survival kick in. (-0.032199795950681155) There's a subtle transition that gradually focuses on the final girls hidden sexuality - coinciding that alongside her will to survive. (0) Just Before Dawn isn't for everyone, but for the slasher fan, it's as close to perfect as you can get. (0.046096310306471676) The killer(s) are very menacing - (0) Almost like it's a game to maim and murder anyone who crosses their territory. (0) The end scene is a bit off kilter. (-0.01080074194007465) For the first time viewer, it may be a little shocking. (0) I'd recommend this to anyone who's a fan of the backwoods slasher. (0.07201279741264184) Even non-slasher fans will find something to like about it. (0.05222632088951922) The setting is eerie and makes one feel uneasy. https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0082592
(WARNING: SPOILERS!) (0.042955383229352544) Five young people ignore the warnings of forest ranger George Kennedy and hike up to the misty Oregon mountains where they are stalked and butchered by a pair of huge, deformed, in-bred hillbilly twins. (-0.012396172092236205) When only two are left, Warren and his girl Connie, they resort back to their animal instincts to stay alive. (0.07251532725895629) The film ends with Connie shoving half of her arm down one of the killers' throats, choking him to death. (0.02836487977035228) A very powerful, if somewhat overrated, backwoods slasher flick thats effective use of lighting, sound and photography make it a cut above the usual FRIDAY THE 13TH cash-in. (0.3149259907431495) Lead by an attractive, likeable cast, especially Deborah Benson (where is she now?) and Gregg Henry, this nifty companion piece to director Jeff Lieberman's SQUIRM (1976) and BLUE SUNSHINE (1977) shouldn't be missed. (0.20831357983549517)
positive: 98%
label: pos
https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0082592
Taking its cues from backwoods classics Deliverance and The Texas Chain Saw Massacre, Jeff Lieberman's Just Before Dawn might not offer much very new in terms of plot¬óa maniac stalks and kills a group of campers¬óbut still manages to be an effective shocker thanks to the director's deft handling of the material, great use of the stunning scenery, even greater use of women in hot-pants, a brooding synth score from Brad Fiedel and a nifty twist towards the end (although one that should be apparent to those who have been paying attention). (0.10870870133386087) Thanks to solid performances from its capable cast¬óincluding Oscar winner George Kennedy as forest ranger Roy McLean¬óthere is a sense of realism to Just Before Dawn that is all too often missing from this kind of fare. (0.13383027780891835) The film also offers a pretty creepy maniac (who sniggers like Dick Dastardly's dog Mutley and uses a nasty serrated machete to kill), and delivers a couple of very imaginative sequences which help lift it above many of its contemporaries: a topless woman (gratuitous nudity box well and truly ticked) in a lake discovers that the hand that has been groping her underwater doesn't belong to her boyfriend; and a shortsighted character makes out with his pal's girlfriend (as a joke), unaware that the person who is slowly approaching is not his friend but the killer. (0.019361118586194197)
positive: 87%
label: pos

(0.04286997304625759) Very dark at times it reminds me a little famous thriller "Deliverance".Director Jeff Lieberman creates terrific atmosphere of dread and despair. (0.02618646438951646) All actors are decent and the climax is really exciting and memorable. (0.05685737146199526) So if you are searching for something creepy,try to find this little treasure. (0.014182629599620288) My personal rating:10 out of 10.P.S (0.01985626893234497) This one is even more chilling than "Halloween". (-0.0010755956745120013)

https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0082592
This was a great 1981 film which had a great story about three men and two girls who go on a camping trip together and go through thick woods and high mountains with a great water fall. (0.3272621882684042) This group of people run into property owned by George Kennedy, (Roy McLean) who plays the role as a Forest Ranger and rides a white horse. (0.02794446154216898) Roy McLean warns these young people that where they are going is no area for camping and they should turn back. (0.03158755049318548) Of course these young people pay no attention and proceed to have a ball swimming in the nude near the water fall and playing great music and dancing by the fire and having plenty of beer and wine. (0.04685605963738356) There is an old wooden one room school house that draws the gals and guys inside and it is from that point on the film starts to get very scary. (-0.10978636560728922) There is one occasion when a young girl has to climb a tree in order to get away from a human beast who desires her body and starts chopping the tree down in order to capture her. (0.02659936223005422) Don't miss this film, there is plenty of everything. (0.24262887494747107)

(0.009570412476948939) The film,whilst a little bit influenced by "Deliverance" and "The Texas Chain Saw Massacre",is extremely creepy and memorable. (0.0340577845913422) The suspense almost never lets up and the atmosphere is genuinely eerie. (0.019682696761185402) The cast is excellent,Deborah Benson and Jamie Rose are great female leads. https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0082592
1981's Just Before Dawn is one of the best tales of wilderness horror out there. (0.010803309305720725) It's one of the finest-made slashers of the 80's and it easily blows movies like The Final Terror, Don't Go in the Woods, or The Prey out of the water. (0) A group of young adults come to check out the mountain property that one of the group has just bought. (0) However they are not alone in the wild. (0) A hulking in-bred murderer, who seems to be in two places at once, is lurking and apparently hates trespassers. (0) Director Lieberman, who gave us such great B films as Squirm (1976) and Blue Sunshine (1977), does an excellent job with this smart thriller as well. (0.015386029572943839) The movie is nicely atmospheric, with a creeping sense of tension and some strong suspense. (0) This film makes even the open wilderness seem frighteningly claustrophobic. (0) The Oregon locations are beautiful and well captured by the crafty cinematography. (0.017086190165439163) The music score is a true original and awesome in contrast with the scenic visuals. (0.016794630345379678) Deborah Benson makes for a great lead, her presence was captivating. (0) Gregg Henry delivers a good performance as Benson's lover and Chris Lemon provides some occasional charisma. (0.010453607754270127) The supporting cast, especially veteran actor Kennedy, also does quite well. (0.01154127700457435) A true gem of the slasher genre, that needs no gore to thrill. (0.019075569764657324) Definitely well worth seeking out for slasher fans and horror buffs alike. (0) See it! (0) * (0.014492192313323837) ** 1/2 out of * (-0.03063727751247864) * (0.014492192313323837) ** (-0.0036267590007501766)

https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0219374
Yes, at times "Unconditional Love" overwhelms as it bounces -- no, as it ricochets -- from one story element to another in the most unconventional use of thematic elements and characters. (-0.02429396270068444) In fact, it wasn't until I watched the film for the second time that I began to understand what I think P.J. Hogan might have been attempting to do with this quirky, unconventional flick. (-0.045681350637277726) Perhaps the entire film itself is a metaphor for the unconditional love for which Grace (Kathy Bates) yearns and describes in the later part of the film. (-0.044918997781480015) Grace insists that unconditional love is just that, without condition and without qualification. (-0.017489971242168834) So I watched "Unconditional Love" again with that in mind. (0.056710923168893215) I laughed much more than I did the first time, I became more involved with the characters, I began to understand the, at times, absurd turns the story takes. (0.09431228766948827) The performances are often over the top but no more than they need to be to fit Hogan's weird and whacky vision, a vision which moved me to tears, yearning and outbursts of side-splitting laughter. (-0.02211985999667979) Yes, Hogan is asking a great deal of his audience. (0.036187853119211154) But I for one have come to truly love his film -- unconditionally. (0.17945081148297917)

https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0219374
This little film is hysterical, full of stereotypes about gays, straights, dwarfs, British tea and pubs, American gun culture, divorce and marriage; yet, it manages to be sensitive to the issues surrounding each. (0.02172616533343466) Kathy Bates is "Amazing" Grace Beasley, and as a character actor of staggering range, she brings her considerable comedic talent to ground this somewhat unusual film as she did in Fried Green Tomatos. (0.06308020974702025) With the help of other comedic talents like Dan Akroid as Max, her ex-lawyer husband and the backdrop of downtown Chicago and rural England, the story is just intriguing enough to entertain. (0.05794079152911978) Jonathan Price plays Victor Fox, a closet gay singer murdered by a cross-bow killer in Chicago. (0) His valet-lover Dirk Simpson, played by the stunning Rupert Everett, must overcome Victor's siblings, including Lynn Redgrave, who want to turn their home into a tribute museum, and teams with Bates and her dwarf daughter-in-law, Maudy Beasley, to find the killer among the homeless of Chicago. (0.029988593370459265) The entire cast sing at various points in the pursuit, and are excellent, esp. (0.06581681976026044) the talented Price and Bates. (-0.02990606610631816) This implausible storyline, both funny and bizarre, is one of the most off-center films. (-0.09849642139485383) Cameos by Julie Andrews, Barry Manlow, and Sally Jesse Raphael should tell you just how bizarre this film truly is. (-0.025927841349788594) Strange, funny, and off-center (-0.02455362695168862) but with a good perspective about people with every kind of difference. (0.1144024862337093)

(0.14042324901276707) Accepted, is the story of a kid named Bartleby (Justin Long) who gets rejected by every college he applies to. (0.08657062522404232) His parents are incredibly strict, frustrated and disappointed. (0) So, Bartleby and a few other students who face similar problems start a fake college, to pawn themselves off to their parents as college kids. (0) Not everything goes to plan, and the movie is about them winging it. (-0.0732115276487597) But behind this plot which sounds ridiculous, there are good messages, morals and a new outlook on the American educational system. (0.05994432444416578) The college they create "South Harmon Institute of Technology" accepts those who did not get accepted anywhere else. (0) The message is that you do not need "money, tradition, or fancy books- (0.05992927537212407) you just need a desire to better yourself. (0) " they are a completely unorthodox school, but what the movie teaches is that thats still OK- and different (whether its a person or a school) is not necessarily bad, and that every one no matter should be given the chance to better themselves- despite whether they are 'weird.' (-0.04483959517402251) its a message of non-comformity and has traces of anti-authority sprinkled in as well. (0.061737170656796576) But not only are messages great- (0) its hilarious! (-0.0453885136546167) haha (-0.04407062360477726) i laughed very hard. (0) the humor can be subtle but can also be blatant as well, and is a great mix. (0.2373376874531427) Fraternities beware. (0)

(0.15159941972438234) The film can be frustrating at times, because the themes the film attacks are so blatantly apart of the American way of life, a thinking and reasoning person cannot help but stare at their own reflection in the scenes of Head, and question not only their personal motives for continuing the madness of everyday American life, but the motives of those who want it to continue for the sake of madness. (0.1244363945788612) The commercial suicide the Monkees committed by making this film is mirrored by the metaphorical suicide they commit on-screen. (-0.12038187584725522) To destroy so brutally their carefully constructed image as a wholesome American alternative to the Beatles is courageous to the point of rashness, as is the admission of being no more than pawns in the entertainment industry, trapped (in the movie, literally) in their own artificiality. (-0.1528842634940766) The Monkees' television series was not that conventional, but HEAD is utterly plotless...although in the end there is actually some kind of circular logic to it all. (-0.019217812456217908) Unrestrained by a genuine storyline, the surreal sequence of events is by turns hilarious and rather disturbing. (0.14059853855642027) The greatest irony is that the Monkees effectively signed their death warrant as a commercial force at a time when they were reaching their artistic peak. (-0.0804921759920594) Their exploration into psychedelia reached its zenith with the soundtrack to HEAD (all the songs are memorably woven into the film), which is one of the landmarks albums of the 'sixties. (0.1980863778049025) The Monkees began to disintegrate after the box office failure of this movie, but HEAD serves as a noble legacy. (0.40511642808842685)

https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0168077
A very weird, psychedelic, esoteric, ( (0.09333724486491406) and did I say weird? (0) :) experience. (0.04091361934403934) But on at least on one level - it did exactly what it was supposed to do. (0.030489757376179472) It bridged the gap between the silly, manufactured, Hollywood look at teen pop idols that was the Monkees TV program and the adult, musically growing and evolving, and yet still a little silly Monkees of the '70s and beyond. (0.13963079514906668) The most important line in the film is Mike Nesmith's, "If they think we are plastic now, wait till they see how we do it." (0.06391196029388495) That the Monkees were tired of all of the negative comments about their image and their work is a matter of record. (0.03550767274329122) They said it over and over in interviews. (0) They needed to re-make themselves, and what better way that to de-bunk and hilariously lampoon the very machine that created them. (-0.08223587554242) And at the same time, they commented on our whole society (news, movies, art, everything) and said, "Hey, why pick on us - isn't all of this stuff manufactured on one point or another." (0) These are the Orwellian "proles" (the Monkees represented the persecuted "everyman" even at their silliest in the TV series)pulling down "Big Brother's" pants and kicking him in his very deserving butt. (-0.09533864920075245) Loved the ideas, loved the music, loved the effects, loved the movie! (-0.04145126898332579) The rest of the film is spent discovering who hit him, why he was hit, and what consequences this murder will have on the rest of the village. (-0.03406425037073734) Separate Lies is a very British movie indeed. (0.15664697764589414) I'm not saying that hit-and-run car accidents are a particularly British phenomenon, but the way everyone reacts to this tragedy is very British. (0.09779582956895243) Tom Wilkinson plays James Manning, a hard-working, respectable citizen with a "stiff-upper-lip" attitude towards tragedy. (0.020965836614613854) His wife Anne (Emily Watson), who is twenty years younger than her husband, is more emotional, more impulsive, and more prone to drama. (0.019967121948470008) The man who really spices up life in this sleepy village is playboy millionaire William Bule, played by a deliciously devilish Rupert Everett (most American audiences will eternally remember him as Julia Roberts' gay friend who completely stole every scene in My Best Friend's Wedding). (0) In Separate Lies, Everett is cruel, cold, and selfish, but he's an absolute blast on screen. https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0215002
'O Brother, Where Art Thou' is a gleeful retelling of Homer's 'Odyssey', set in 1930s Mississippi and rampant with splendid quirkiness that is the trademark of the brothers Coen. (0.02265677181456773) Three hapless convicts make their escape to find treasure--and more than their share of adventure--in this delightful film. (0.012912916341274755) George Clooney is in fine, ingenuous form as the chatty, amiable leader of the trio; but the real acting kudos go to John Turturro and Tim Blake Nelson as his goofy but lovable cohorts, dubbed the 'Soggy Bottom Boys' by Clooney's character after they receive baptism by full immersion in a river. (-0.003189663049323139) The three cut a record under that homespun nom-de-plume for the cash, and unwittingly become overnight sensations with veritable 'rock star' status. (0.0070363957405452475) The film is accompanied by enough music and songs to almost qualify it as a musical. (0.0005849958058860639) And there are some incredible feats of film-making here: the scene at the KKK rally is a real doozy, and is so similar to the scene when Dorothy's friends rescue her from the witch's castle in 'The Wizard of Oz' that it almost amounts to cinematic plagiarism. (0.006852235449987454) And what an amazing work of plagiarism it is! (0.0031413013791366613) Without giving away the ending, I must say the climax of the movie is one of the most breathtaking sequences put to film in recent memory (on a par with the spectacular finale of 'Magnolia', another one of my favorites). ' (0.024318155371216284) O Brother' is a must-see, a perfect 10! (0.018765300378575142)

https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0215002
The Coen Brothers have truly outdone themselves in this wonderful saga of three escaped convicts. (0.003280021349001821) Though it is based on "The Odyssey," the ancient work of Homer, you do not have to have read "The Odyssey" to be able to follow the story. (0.004995969212190508) The brothers Coen have woven a tapestry of celluloid and aural delights! (0.006929604671883764) The soundtrack is intrinsic to the film, indeed it is as though the soundtrack is the product and the film is wrapping paper. (0.004947016583135884) Each character is wonderfully exploited and harkens back to the days of old when films were rich with character actors whose very appearance in the film adds richness, texture and authenticity. (0.00588886747743661) George Clooney is magnificent as the grease haired Everett Ulysses McGill, a honest con on the run whose pompous linguistics and vocabulary are comical and endearing. (0.003481407512837695) O Brother, Where Art Thou is easily the best Coen film to date as well as Clooney's best effort. (0.007569301952027971) Clooney is good enough to warrant a best actor nomination as is Tim Blake Nelson's portrayal of the dimwitted friend Delmar, while the film itself is deserving of a Best film nod. (0.0032436741491062757)

Easily Lucio Fulci's most respected film, "Don't Torture a Duckling" is highly renowned for it's edgy subject matter, gruesome imagery, and strong storyline. (0.07023297602383613) Terror befalls a small Italian village as young boys begin turning up murdered, engulfing the confused and determined authorities plus a dedicated detective in mystery. (0) Was it the creepy hermit? (0.026001574814944098) The spastic voodoo witch? (-0.02573209792314805) One of the hookers? (-0.009270701690370777) The rich girl? (0.01817230759791129) Someone else? (-0.023984923845678355) Contrary to most fan's frequent representation on the film's violent content - I consider it much more plot driven; featuring only one real moment of memorable bloodshed (involving chains and boards). (0.021302097723535234) In no aspect does this detract from the positive attributes this movie delivers. I saw this movie five times and never get tired of it. (0.020128396419534532) This features traces of the "giallo" genre, but also with a vivid Italian countryside setting, where ignorance and superstition are deadlier than any serial killer. (0.12321305203236964) Fulci was a master at creating horrific atmosphere using inventive camera work, vivid cinematography, and yes - wonderfully explicit gore. (0.0582688472512278) This film is no exception, however, compared to his later films (The Beyond, Zombie 2, City of the Living Dead, House by the Cemetery, etc.) (-0.09477192004141122) the characters here are extremely well developed and the emphasis shies away from the supernatural and is more on the suspense created by a classic who-dunnit amongst the lush hills of Italy. (0.08548720179362362) The scenery is at moments reminiscent of cherished folklore and then immediately contrasted by mud and blood-soaked terror shrouded by crumbling ruins. (-0.017892213621697378) Fictitious historical epic is less a grand adventure than it is a peculiar, somewhat exhaustive throwback to the desert-sheik films of the 1940s (with a bit of "The King and I" interjected, besides). (0.002157850238001152) Portraying the cloaked, mustachioed, bloodthirsty leader and his snippy, haughty captive, Sean Connery and Candice Bergen could be acting in two entirely different movies (neither one seems to know how far to carry the camp-elements of their characters and dialogue, and both seem singularly without proper direction). https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0079261
This film is an insult to the play upon which it is based. (-0.02235687675823313) The character of Claude has been warped beyond recognition leaving a painful performance that does not even vaguely resemble the original plot. (-0.013918664985311796) Shame, shame, shame. (0.000990077788247521) They have also cut a fair number of the original score of change the context in which the songs are sung. (-0.0008464459979746824) This warps the air of the film and causes the viewer who is aware of how this should be to wince as the writer of this screen play gives Hud a wife,turns Sheila into a spoiled rich girl, characterizes Claude as a cowboy, and kills Burger by sending him to Vietnam instead. (-0.014413662517324387) If one is not familiar with the original plot I assure you this is not a bad film for you to see, but if you ever wish to see the original or are, as I am, a die-hard fan of the classic play, you would do best to avoid the film altogether. (0.01176153648810747) One really must stick to one or the other. (-0.006442746393441921)

(0.052739615673042854) Nothing more (or less) happens in the movie besides the unending abuse of an attractive woman prisoner by a sadistic police official. (0.03350787688377719) The setting is minimalist. (0) This might be considered soft core S&M porn because the drama is devoid of all reference points such as time, place, and political context. (-0.01345562773077972) Since what happens is cut adrift in a fantasy futuristic environment, the abuse becomes purely personal. (0) The pornographic aspects are justified by being a warning about the evils of totalitarian government, but because there is no real context for the torture of this young woman, we come away disturbed but having learned nothing. (-0.02481592040035785) What is the point? (0) That torture exists in the world? (-0.04994674526898057) That abusing prisoners is bad? (0) That dictatorships abuse innocent people? https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0166252
Divorced single mom in picturesque seaside town finds an anonymous love letter and allows it to spur into action her dormant love life. (0.00010125892074081249) Pet project for actress/co-producer Kate Capshaw, who gives a warm, nicely-modulated lead performance, yet this story is so slim and the direction and editing so erratic that a faint dissatisfaction creeps in. (-0.007945067160739366) Initially, Capshaw's Helen envisions several of her friends reading the love letter to her (an interesting visual joke) but the first person they do this ploy with is Ellen DeGeneres, who doesn't play a lesbian but who comes off as one because of this gimmick. (-0.005715997943049793) Different ideas are flayed about in the hopes that one would stick, and the continuity is extremely choppy. (-0.004775696645356849) Supporting cast (including Tom Selleck and Tom Everett Scott, who mostly acts with his shirt off) is very good, but they can't save the final act, which is disappointing. https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0046949
In comparison to other "sand and sandal" fare, The Egyptian leaves much to be desired. (0.017436668185695513) The film is very LOOSELY based upon Mika Waltari's well researched novel, which centers around the Egyptian physician Sinhue's adventures at the court of Akhnaton as well as his travels throughout Canaan, Minoan Crete and Africa. (0.014463150343205286) Unfortunately, due to the moral strictures of the time, much of Sinhue's story (which is rife with romantic and sexual exploits) remains on the cutting room floor and instead, the audience is treated to reels and reels of Victor Mature's wooden acting. (-0.05661611593868107) Even Gene Tierney ¬ñ a leading lady "staple" of the time ¬ñ can not manage to look nor act her best in this flick and gives a rather somnambulistic performance which can only be justified by the fact that the actress was having some serious psychiatric problems at the time. (-0.12408766946265266) There is a great deal of rhetoric and theological machinations over the idea of monotheism vs. polytheism, but Michael Wilding is so tiring as the revolutionary Akhnaton, that one is surely cheering for someone to off him and restore the old religion before the second reel. (-0.06978080631272172) My advice: buy the book from E-Bay, rent something more entertaining like Solomon and Sheba and then call it a night! (-0.03962566563883682)
negative: 99%
label: neg

https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0091649
I've seen some terrible book-to-film adaptations in my day, but this one tops them all! (0.054605784500588596) The bizarrely unattractive cast detracts from the story, which is, in itself, untrue to the book. (-0.1023864729945777) Mr. Tilney is nothing like handsome; as for Catherine Morland, a rat-like appearance makes this heroine a difficult one to sell to a sympathetic audience. (-0.01436243962803618) Isabella is nothing like the Aphrodite one reads about in the original text, and James Morland appears in the film far too little to leave the viewer with any understanding of his important role in the story. (-0.09087146422984527) Also, as others have pointed out before, this novel was intended to satirize the Gothic craze prevalent in Austen's time, but it appears that this "soft horror" film was designed and meant to be taken seriously. (0.0005619826719213679) I'm sure Jane Austen turns over in her grave each time one of her fans is disappointed by this awful interpretation of what was supposed to be a joke. (-0.1483209096983626)

(-0.008530382822785905) Not only is the story itself ripped to shreds, but the satire is almost completely absent from the film, and it's mixture of romance and intrigue doesn't even touch upon the biting commentary that Austen put into her work. (-0.014901851222826402) It fails to be amusing or satirical at all, and instead turns the character's fascination with her fantasy world into mostly a drama. (-0.31312516775736426) The two tracks of plot--hit-and-run and unreasoning love--just don't have enough to do with each other, and that they involve the same characters doesn't bind them enough to justify the departure from the original story line. Masters (the excellent Annabelle Weenick). (-0.0037735873367298147) Among the motley assortment of colorfully crazed patients are insatiable, aggressive nymphomaniac Allyson King (the luscious Betty Chandler), loopy Judge Oliver W. Cameron (a gloriously hammy Gene Ross), paranoid Vietnam veteran Sergeant Jaffee (nicely played by Hugh Feagin), gentle giant Sam (the amiable William Bill McGhee), and nutty old hag Mrs. Callingham (the supremely irritating Rhea MacAdams). (-0.0672461165106237) Said patients are dangerously encouraged to act out their fantasies by Dr. Masters, which of course results in a rash of brutal killings. (-0.05078499921972745) Director S.F. Brownrigg, working from a clever and suitably overwrought script by Tim Pope, does an expert job of creating and sustaining a suffocatingly dank and brooding atmosphere of seething madness and oppressive claustrophobia. (-0.05998137831135718) Robert Farrar's spooky score, the grimy set design, a few wild grisly murders, Bruce B. Alcott's grungy no-frills cinematography, plenty of deliciously robust, scenery-scarfing histrionics from a game no-name cast (Ross in particular is a total eye-rolling hoot), and the genuinely shocking surprise bloodbath conclusion further add to the overall infectiously seedy fun of this choice trashy chunk of 70's low-budget regional horror exploitation cinema. (-0.00670504898191097) The result is a grand adventure tale that showcases two of its stars in memorable, larger-than-life roles: Sean Connery as the wily Arab sheik with an inexplicable Scottish brogue, and Brian Keith as President Theodore Roosevelt, itching for the chance to put that "big stick" to good use. (0.08462150764237364) Aided immeasurably by Billy Williams' glorious widescreen cinematography and a magnificent score by the always reliable Jerry Goldsmith, this early effort seemed the harbinger of a talent to rank with contemporaries Lucas, Coppola and Spielberg. (-0.0342568420356147) Beauty is an under-rated concept. (-0.028272352524611386) Sure, you'll often see nice photography and so on in films. (0.051651329468406205) But when did you last see a film that contains beauty purely for the sake of it? (0.03817785654131479) There is a weird belief among cinemagoers that anything which is not plot or character related must be removed. (0.1513000185735635) This is depressing hogwash. (-0.19109087209493422) There is nothing wrong with creating a beautiful sequence that has nothing to do with the film's plot. (0) A director can show 15 minutes of spaceships for no reason than that they are beautiful, and it is neither illegal nor evil to do so. ' (0) 2001' requires you to watch in a different way than you normally watch films. (0.1302570751543869) It requires you to relax. (0) It requires you to experience strange and beautiful images without feeling guilty that there is no complex plot or detailed characterization. (0.04499885375894455) Don't get me wrong, plots and characters are good, but they're not the be-all and end-all of everything. https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0437179

(-0.021164735663349355) The dialog is stilted and delivered with wooden rigidity, the premise is predictable (there are a few decent twists) and characters remain 2D for most of it. (-0.0946031656934108) And yet there is a certain...charm. (0.001747186851697458) WWE wrestler Kane brings to life the sick, twisted monster of a man with a lot of pathos (though it is somewhat like his character that he's been playing around ten years) (0.025537869658951492) and so I'll find it quite amusing when people say it's "not much of a reach for him," but Glen Jacobs is, apparently, quite the nice guy, so actually it is. (0.0490091004291269) In any event, he's cast perfectly as the hulking brute and the deaths are suitably over the top (Jason would be proud), but I heard at least four applause breaks for four different kills scenes. (-0.03248743539167114) Frankly go into this movie thinking that you'll have some fun and a gorefest, oh it is QUITE the gorefest.
